title: Wave properties - rank speeds on strings 1 2 3

content.question: Mass per Length Tension String <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> <math alttext="lambda" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>λ</mi></math> <math alttext="T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>T</mi></math> String <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> <math alttext="2 lambda" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mi>λ</mi></math> <math alttext="T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>T</mi></math> String <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math> <math alttext="lambda" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>λ</mi></math> <math alttext="2 T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mi>T</mi></math> Waves travel along three different strings: String <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, String <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, and String <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math>. Each string is made of the same material but does not necessarily have the same diameter. The mass per length of each string and the tension in each string are given in the table. Which of the following correctly compares the speeds <math alttext="v sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>, <math alttext="v sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, and <math alttext="v sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math> of the waves on strings <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, and <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math>, respectively?

choices.label: <math alttext="v sub 1, end sub, equals, v sub 2, end sub, which equals, v sub 3, end sub" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math>

<math alttext="open parenthesis, v sub 1, end sub, equals v sub 3, end sub, close parenthesis, is greater than, v sub 2, end sub" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded><mo>></mo><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>

<math alttext="v sub 3, end sub, is greater than, open parenthesis, v sub 1, end sub, equals v sub 2, end sub, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo>></mo><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math>

<math alttext="v sub 3, end sub, is greater than, v sub 1, end sub, which is greater than, v sub 2, end sub" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>

content.answer: <math alttext="v sub 3, end sub, is greater than, v sub 1, end sub, which is greater than, v sub 2, end sub" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>

topic.text: 14.1: Properties of Wave Pulses and Waves

skill.text: 2.C: Compare physical quantities between two or more scenarios or at different times and locations in a single scenario.
